history.content:
EE120 followed by EE C106A? I don't think 106A asks for 120 as a necessary prerequisite, just recommended to take 120 prior to 106A, and from what I've heard 120 is pretty handy for the robotics domain.

---------

If you want hands-on application, EE 106A labs do a good job teaching ROS, which is the main framework used in robotics. Unless you already are familiar with ROS or plan on self learning it, taking 106A is a very good idea. Theory wise, the course also teaches you fundamentals of rigid body motions, forward kinematics, inverse kinematics, and localization/mapping, all incredibly fundamental to robotics. The final project will also be incredibly useful in building on what you've learned in class/labs and getting research/internships/jobs in robotics.

----------

EE120 isn't really needed for 106A. Linear algebra familiarity and upper div mathematical maturity are expected, but there are many other classes which give you that background. EE128 is somewhat useful for 106A, and is very useful for 106B.

ME 136 is a bit lighter than 106A. ME 193B is a bit heavier. ME 231A and 231B are also pretty good application-based classes, as opposed to EE 221A, which is more theory-heavy.

I highly recommend 106A/B, but as a TA I'm very biased.

EE C106A + possibly C106B, though I have heard some murmurs about the latter being a bit disorganized? All hearsay, I haven't personally taken those but was considering them several moons ago. Note that 106A asks for 120 as a prerequisite, so maybe 120 followed by 106A?

children.subject: So do Dragan, Bajcsy, Fearing, Goldberg, and every other robotics professor, even prof Sastry. In the mechE department there's Stuart, Borrelli, Mueller, Sreenath, Tomizuka, Agogino, and Kazerooni (though he's just design). The learning people only like super high GPA's, but it's much easier getting research with other robotics profs.

ee 192 or an upper div in mech e controls or design innovation sounds good for you. EE 120, EE 221A are good start off points, also talk with professors Hannah Stuart and Francisco Borelli in Mech E [and if your GPA is hot, Abeel, Levine and Tomlin have undergrad research assistants]

106B is a more project oriented class structured like a graduate course and focuses a lot on the task of robotic grasping. If you are looking for just foundations, 106A is enough. If you want to get into cutting edge research in robotics, 106B is recommended.
Would I be missing out on anything if I took EEC106A and not B?

history.content:
Hi, 

I'm thinking about taking a few EE robotics courses, but I'm looking at my schedule and I may only have time to browse one or two of them. I want to do a lot of what was done in the TI  project for EE16B. I wanted to know if anyone had any suggestions about which ones best suit my interests and also which ones can be taken concurrently. Also, if anyone knows of a good Jacobs Course, that would be nice as well.
history.subject: Suggestion Robotics Courses
